Hi J.B,

I think the original poster wants a log of all the assertions that=
 are being
run.  Whether the tests are simple (one assertion per test) or c=
omplex is an
orthogonal issue.

This feature request has come up a few time=
s on the TestNG mailing-list as
well, and I have sometimes felt this need o=
ccasionally myself.

Think of it as another granularity level of insight in=
side your tests:  if
you want the big picture, you look at the HTML reports=
.  If you want the
fine picture, you look at the source.  And if you want s=
omething in-between
("are we making sure the collection is the right size?"=
), you could use this
hypothetical assert log without the source noise.

--=
 
C=E9dric


On Mon, Jun 9, 2008 at 3:30 PM, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@=
gmail.com>
wrote:


On 2008-06-09, at 07:23 , Phil Surette wrote:

> I'd li=
ke to make a case for adding logging of assertions into junit.
> I've been =
using junit for many years, and something that I've found
> both for myself=
 and for people who I've mentored in XP practices is
> that it is often hel=
pful to get warm fuzzy feedback that your tests
> are running and asserting=
 what you think they are asserting.
>
> I notice that I'm not alone in this=
; I see there are several threads
> where people were looking for this feat=
ure
> (http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/17845 "how to log
>=
 junit tests", http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/18762
> "ju=
nit 4 & logging",
> http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/12000 =
"Log4J Logging
> in JUnit")
>
I am just going to be frank here. Yes, many p=
eople have said they want
to log assertions in tests because they want the =
warm fuzzy feedback
that their tests are running and assertion what they th=
ink they are
asserting. Logging is just one, and in my opinion a bad, way t=
o do
this. I believe it is much better to write simpler tests.
> 1) elimina=
ting redundant logging statements - Many logging statements
> in a JUnit te=
st case simply output information that you've already
> told JUnit about in=
 your assertions. Developers often put these in as
> a 'sanity check' to ve=
rify that the test is doing what they expected.
>
If your tests need such a=
 sanity check, then I believe they should be
simpler.
> 2) improving assert=
ion messages - it's often the case that the
>
> first time you see the mess=
age for an assertion will be when the
> assertion fails, which may not happ=
en until you run a regression test
> many moons after you coded the test. U=
nless you see the message
> displayed when you are developing the test, you=
 won't realize that the
> message - if you provided one - is not be very he=
lpful. Better
> assertion messages also help to communicate to a developer =
what the
> point of the assertion is both when it fails and when reading th=
e
> test.
>
If you aren't going to think about the failure message when you=
 write
it, then don't write one.
> 3) see finer-grain test results. Every a=
ssertion is a mini-test on its
> own, but JUnit these mini-tests are invisi=
ble until they fail.
>
Absolutely not. Assertions are not mini-tests. A tes=
t is a test. If
you have multiple unrelated assertions in a test, then move=
 them into
their own tests. This leads to a number of benefits (more accura=
te
test count metrics, more information when a test fails, easier to
isolat=
e the cause of a failure).
> 4) by making logging easy, it can help to avoi=
d the
> using-system-outs-instead-of-asserts syndrome, where new junit test=

> writers will write "test cases" that actually just write a bunch of
> st=
uff to the console that the test writer then eyeballs for expected
> result=
s
>
Why would anyone use JUnit to spit things out to the console? If they
w=
ant output on the console, and they're not just using that as a way
to lear=
n to use JUnit, then they shouldn't use JUnit.
> There are some problems wi=
th logging assertions that I have
> encountered:
>
> 1) if iterating over a=
 collection and asserting each element, your log
> can be overwhelmed. Mayb=
e it would be useful to have some way of
> hinting that a particular assert=
ion should not create notifications;
> maybe not.
>
I don't even want to th=
ink about how slowly tests will run, and how
much time I would waste decidi=
ng which tests should log what and when.
It's much easier just to add loggi=
ng where I want it.
> Is there any appetite out there for adding assertion =
logging (or
> assertion notification) into the junit 4 framework? I would b=
e
> happy to do the work if I thought it would be accepted into the
> main =
junit distribution. Or maybe this capability already exists
> in some way i=
n junit 4 that I am not aware of?
>
Yes, there is such an appetite, but I h=
ope there is a bigger appetite
not to include it.
